newsitem.title: USA: GM posts best North American profit in a decade.
newsitem.headline: GM posts best North American profit in a decade.

text.p: General Motors Corp., posting its best North American vehicle profits in a decade, said Monday it earned $1.8 billion from continuing operations in the first quarter, up from strike-crippled year-ago earnings of $800 million.
The March 1996 strike at two GM brake plants in Dayton, Ohio, slashed the year-earlier earnings by $900 million and forced the shutdown of 26 GM assembly plants and numerous components plants.
But GM roared back this year with first-quarter profits equal to $2.30 a share, up from 93 cents in the first quarter of 1996, as its sales grew to $42.26 billion from $39.24 billion.
The 1996 results excluded $219 million in profits from Electronic Data Systems Corp., which GM spun off last year.
The 1997 first-quarter performance exceeded Wall Street's consensus estimates of $2.09 a share.
GM stock rose 62.5 cents to $53.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Leading the way for GM was a $764 million profit from its North American vehicle operations, which compared with a year-earlier loss of $279 million in the first quarter of 1996. GM attributed $750 million of its year-ago strike losses to the North American Operations.
Boiling out the strike impact from year ago results, GM said it managed to boost North American profit margins despite an increase in retail incentives to $860 per vehicle from $598 a year earlier.
GM Chief Financial Officer J. Michael Losh attributed the gains to material cost savings and manufacturing efficiencies partly due to the launch of new, lower-cost vehicles.

"As we go through the year, I expect NAO (North American Operations) to improve their market share, particularly in the second half of the year, and I expect them to continue to have year-to-year profit improvements," Losh said.

GM's Delphi Automotive Systems parts unit, making its first quarterly report separate from the core automotive results, posted net income of $180 million for the period. The total included an after-tax charge of $50 million for the closing of a parts plant in Trenton, N.J.
Delphi earned a profit of $79 million in the first quarter of 1996, which included a $120 million negative strike impact.
Analysts said the North American results provided an encouraging sign that GM's turnaround is progressing.
"If you get the same market scenario for the next two to three years, GM is in a position to produce record results in 1997 and in 1998 as well," said PaineWebber analyst Michael Ward.

But GM's European operations struggled under the weight of a fiercely competitive market, with first quarter operating profits falling to $94 million from $285 million a year ago. European incentives rose to $622 per vehicle during the quarter from $598 a year earlier.
The operating results excluded a gain of $55 million from the $1.1 billion settlement in January of GM's industrial espionage dispute with Germany's Volkswagen AG.

Including the gain, GM's International Operations -- which comprise the automaker's European, Latin American and Asia/Pacific operations -- reported net income of $317 million in the latest quarter, compared with earnings of $432 million in the prior-year period.
GM Chairman Jack Smith, speaking to reporters Monday at a business luncheon in Cleveland, said GM was disappointed in the European results, but knew the market would be tough.
"The economies are not strong (in Europe) and we're seeing a lot of price pressure in the marketplace," he said.
General Motors Acceptance Corp., GM's financing unit, also surprised analysts with a 20.4 percent earnings improvement to $372 million, due partly to capital gains in GMAC's insurance unit.
GM said its worldwide wholesale vehicle sales to dealers rose 11.6 percent in the first quarter to 2.19 million from 1.96 million in the year-ago period.

GM said its retail vehicle deliveries in the United States in the first quarter of 1997 totalled 1,123,000 units, resulting in a 30.2-percent share of the U.S. market. That compared with 1,152,000 units and a 31.2-percent share in the first quarter of 1996.

GM is the second of Detroit's Big Three to report first quarter earnings. Chrysler Corp. said last week its net income rose 2.4 percent to $1.03 billion, while Ford Motor Co. is due to report its results Wednesday.
